Expectation1: Provide guidance and wisdom based on life experience
Situation1: The grandmother notices her grandchild seems to be feeling lost or discouraged about a personal matter.
Expectation2: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation2: The launch date was moved up and architects from multiple teams are blocked until they provide decisions
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, my laptop open and Slack notifications pinging relentlessly. The product manager’s message blinked at the top: “Need your input on the API changes ASAP—architects are waiting.” My calendar was a wall of overlapping meetings, all suddenly urgent since the launch date was moved up. I rubbed my temples, trying to focus, when I heard a soft sniffle from the living room. My granddaughter sat curled on the couch, her eyes red and distant. I knew that look—something was weighing on her, something she didn’t know how to say. My heart ached to go to her, to offer the comfort and perspective only a grandparent can give. But the pressure from work was crushing; teams were blocked, and everyone was waiting on me. I felt torn in two, the demands of my job and the needs of my family pulling me in opposite directions. My hands hovered over the keyboard, my mind racing with code and compassion, unsure which world needed me more in this moment.
